# Of beauty and tomatoes 

Below you can see the correlation between the import value of tomatoes in Germany and the number of cosmetic surgeries world wide. 

## Cosmetic surgeries and tomato import value

::: {.cell hash='04_causality_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_403a483ac09b7a47f36acc19b2441a5c'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
library(jtools)
AB <- read.csv("../../../Causal_Data_Science_Data/AB.csv")
scale <- 0.55
y_str2 <-'Tomato import in Germany [100kâ‚¬]'
y_str1 <- 'Cosmetic surgeries world wide'
p <- ggplot(AB, aes(x=Jahr, y=OP)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = y_str1)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Wert/scale,  color = y_str2)) +
  scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~.*scale, name=y_str2)) +
  labs(x = "Year", y = y_str1 )
p + theme_apa() + theme(legend.position="bottom")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](04_causality_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

## Correlation

::: {.cell hash='04_causality_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_1e6338b7527e064b8e408fdab1b2eb94'}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit <- lm(AB$OP ~ AB$Wert)
fit_R2 <- cor(AB$OP, AB$Wert)
fit_R2 <- sprintf("%0.2f",fit_R2)
```
:::

As you can imagine their is no causal link between the two. Nerveless, there is a significant correlation between both variables. The Pearson correlation coefficient is $R = 0.80$. Both samples are normaly distributed.
